name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 4th Place Runner
description: This was the Runner deck piloted by Mykel Kramer at the Colorado Regional. Mykel went 4-4 with it and finished 7th in Swiss and 4th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: 2014 Regional Championship @ Guardian Games - Corp
description: Kyle James' winning corp deck form the 2014 Regional Championship @ Guardian Games (Portland, OR) May 10th

name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 5th Place Runner
description: This was the Runner deck piloted by Tim Bunn at the Colorado Regional. Tim went 5-2 with it and finished 2nd in Swiss and 5th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 6th Place Runner
description: This was the Runner deck piloted by Jason Niehoff at the Colorado Regional. Jason went 5-3 with it and finished 5th in Swiss and 6th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 7th Place Corp
description: This was the Corp deck piloted by Mark Chamberlain at the Colorado Regional. Mark went 4-3 with it and finished 6th in Swiss and 7th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 7th Place Runner
description: This was the Runner deck piloted by Mark Chamberlain at the Colorado Regional. Mark went 5-2 with it and finished 6th in Swiss and 7th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 8th Place Corp
description: This was the Corp deck piloted by Joshua Ely at the Colorado Regional. Joshua went 3-4 with it and finished 8th in Swiss and 8th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: 2014 Colorado Regional - 8th Place Runner
description: This was the Runner deck piloted by Joshua Ely at the Colorado Regional. Joshua went 5-2 with it and finished 8th in Swiss and 8th in the double-elimination bracket.

name: Bullet to the Face
description: I am new at this but I built this with the idea of tagging the runner and flatlining him primarily with meat damage. I have messed with it and tampered but it still isnt perfect. Moderately successful but. Am also new so as i get better, so does this deck. Any advice would be wonderful. It has won all its games, but it has been too close several times (all games meaning 4 games). I encountered Plascrete for the first time and it made things very difficult so i changed things up including changing my identity.

name: Iain Stirling has Connections (and Donuts) v2
description: Iain needs time to rekindle all his old relationships in the underworld, but once he does he will come out of retirement in a big way! Pressure central servers while setting up a massive social network of connections and then call in those favors for the ultimate massive bankroll. The cost of Crypsis to hit the remotes wont even matter when you are sitting on so much cash.

name: Woman Theory
Woman Theory
NarcoWiz
NarcoWiz
Slowboat to Hades
Jinteki Death and Taxes v1.1
description:
2-1 at local Game Night event. The deck was still good, I'm not sure whether or not the changes improved it at all. My loss was to a very aggressive runner who managed to pull agendas off the top of R&D with single access on both the first and second turns.

I believe in the next iteration the snares will likely come out for something else, and I would like to take a look at a different ice setup.

name: The Network v0.1
description:
0-3 at local Game Night. The deck was both a little too slow anda little too inefficient to compete. Lost to HB all three rounds - defeated a Jinteki before the tournament began however. Perhaps this result simply points to the fact that this deck is very bad at face-checking bioroid ice, or maybe that it isn't efficient enough to defeat big ice in general.

I'm not really sure where to go with this. A more varied icebreaker suite might be the first place to start, but the resource requirement to make the combo operate is so dense that there is hardly any room for anything else. I did find that AS was terrible in this deck, as I was never able to get through to HQ efficiently, nor early. For the same reason, Legwork and the Unregistered S&W were both suboptimal as well. I would probably start cutting from there and try to make the combo more efficient.

name: Weyland
Andromeda
Office Space
description:
This is an updated version of the 1st place winner from the Phoenix Regional.

(Note = 1st Place out of 56 players!!)

The current ICE is being tested as compared to other HBFA's ICE. Most of it is standard except for the 2 Rainbows.

I will say that Efficiency Committee + Shipment from SanSan is FANFUCKINGTASTIC!

name: If You Die on the Net ...
description: A Jinteki kill deck designed to be efficient in destroying the runner's resources. Installing Chairman Hiro early can both reduce the Runner's access to their best cards and make it easier to kill with either a Snare or even Shi.Kyu. Just make sure to protect Hiro with some of that fancy Bioroid Ice. If that fails early, you can always just start advancing Medical Breakthroughs.

name: Rez and Repeat
Gabe - Notorious Doppleganger
description:
Relatively simple deck. Centrals only breakers leading to milling R&D for agendas, the Femmes used to neutralise high cost sentries or other problem ice, the scavenges designed to reposition the femmes to allow me to access what the runner thinks are safe remotes quickly if needed. New Angeles enables me to avoid the tags from account siphon and keep Ms. Jones safe. Doppleganger allows multiple runs (i.e. siphon then run a remote, or double R&D runs) which also increases the chance of scoring a notoriety or two, something that irritates harmony medtech no end and goes a long way towards countering the pains of Shi-Kyu. It can struggle a bit late game especially once the corp has realised you are running centrals only, something Kati Jones goes a long way towards countering, but at that point, you can easily trash Jacksons where needed and out dig the corps draw from R&D.

I used to run emergency shutdown in it, but discovered I wasn't really using it at all, so threw New Angeles City Hall in instead to counter tag punishment. Any thoughts on this, are much appreciated, as it is pretty much my first runner deck (bar a Chaos Theory one that I hated).

name: Hanzo Rush
description:
So here's the basic janky battle plan:

-Set up your scoring server with SanSan

-Quickly get ahead on an agenda point or two (hopefully a House of Knives)

-Defend either HQ or R&D up the wazoo, and install Tori Hanzo in the central that's least defended (depends on matchup. You basically want to make multiaccesses more trouble than they're worth)

-As the runner makes panic runs towards either central to try and win, keep pinging with Tori and Net Damage

-Either win by the flatline or agendas

No idea if it will work, or if Personal Evolution would be a better fit, using the sansan influence elsewhere, but I thought it was a neat idea.

name: Anarchist Criminal
description: Yeah....why not?

name: ♌ Old School Stirling 2
description:
My first try with the new criminal identities. With only two well-known connections, this isn't Iain and his buddies. I'm more interested by the couple Stirling / Logos. I hope Stirling isn't the runner who loses very rich.

There isn't a lot of new tricks in this deck, although Stirling + Logos is enough to force a new tempo for both the Runner and the Corp.

I don't want to steal an agenda too early with this deck. I think it would be detrimental. The early game is devoted to installation and siphoning.

The most important thing is to install Logos as soon as possible. I mulligan without Logos or (Express Delivery + 1 econ card + 1 breaker). There's a lot of sources of incomes to help the early game: Sure Gamble, Dirty Laundry, and Daily Casts. Kati is reserved for the mid and late game. I don't want to waste clicks loading Kati too early.

I avoid face-checking. The last thing I want is to steal an agenda before the Corp. At least, not until I'm fully installed.

For this reason, the early game could be disturbing because the Corp could score a naked agenda if she dares, although, with Logos installed, this helps the Runner a lot.

It is there that the situation is interesting. A cautious Corp should not score an agenda too early (when Logos is in play). At least, certainly not a 2/1 agenda like Hostile Takeover. The consequences could be really devastating. The Corp should build a good position before all.

There's a lot of breakers and tutors in this deck. As soon as you have a Faerie and a Passport or a Corroder, you can blindly siphon the Corp. Even if doesn't work, you can replay the card later with Same old Thing.

I prefer to remove the tags with Lawyer Up, so I draw three new cards, maybe another Account Siphon or something useful. The VoicePAD can pay for the Lawyer Up, this is great.

The VoicePAD, helped by Passport and Faerie, provides a protection for the Corroder against Power Shutdown. They are also an additional source of incomes, of course, but I add them mostly for the Corroder protection.

I prefer Crash Space over Plascrete Carapace when I play Criminal because I'm not fond of tag-me, specially against NBN and Weyland. It's just a matter of preference and the Carapace is good too, of course.

Once you have installed Corroder, Gordian Blade or Passport, Garrote, and Medium, you can start to hammer R&D. This is the main strategy. Nihil novum sub sole.

If you feel the Corp has some agendas in hand, it's time to play Legwork. I think one is enough if played at the right time, but you can same-old-thing it later if necessary.

I have removed all expose cards in this version for the better or the worse. I have to test this deck against a wider range of Corp decks to see if it was a good idea.

name: Nicey Division
description:
Updated my experimentation with Nisei Division. This deck has basically been flatlining every single runner on OCTGN. Results very good. Strategy is to set up a taxing remote, and continuously install assets and agendas behind it, or bare, out in the open. Lots of punishment in this deck, which can paralyze a runner. Play fast and loose. Possibly tournament viable due to unexpected nature of deck. One of the most fun decks I've ever played--I love it.

You'll be surprised how many foolhardy Criminals you'll murder or drain their bank accounts just because they don't remove tags after a Siphon. Account Siphon is one of this deck's best friends.

VULNERABLE TO: Losing the Psi game lol

name: Gabe centrals + parasite
description:
Haven't played yet. Would like to test gabe parasite with the new planned assault and central-only breakers. Went with 2x clone chip and redundancy of breakers so I could still run into remotes without fearing destroyers.

I'm the least sure about shutdown, notoriety, and clone chip.

name: The Shippest of Shapes
description:
Having a lot of fun playing this very Shapery deck. I think a deck like this is a great way to learn to play shaper, it tries to focus on their core competences, tutor, recursion, and efficient card draw. I learned a lot from playing it, and it's won me a lot of games, but your mileage may vary. It doesn't have any real tricks, just efficient breakers and efficient ways to get them out when you need them.

The Core of the deck is the quartet of Smc, Test run, Clone chip, and Scavenge. Such a powerful tutor and recursion platform provides a lot of flexibility for how to build your deck, since you only need 1 of your breakers, so you get lots of wiggle room for interesting additions and splashes.

The breaker selection is maybe a bit unusual but it gives you really great solutions to a lot of common ice. Usually, you go in one of two directions; either your opponent is moving quickly with cheap ice, in which case you go with cheap breakers that get you in places early, like inti, low strength atman, and mimic. Alternatively, against slower more taxing decks you invest in getting some really efficient breakers on the board, i.e. morning star and torch. The deus X and sharpshooter are there in a pinch to save you from bad things. The atman and femme are both utility breakers for whatever you can't break easily with the other options, as well as your only way past barriers that morning star can't break.

Imp is the only 'trick' in the deck, though it is there mostly for trashing expensive economy assets, like eve or pad campaign. However, it is also your only defence against NBN scorch decks or other CI or Weyland builds that land tags through alternative means than sea source. It's not great defence, but those decks haven't been too prevalent in my local meta, so matching Econ with Weyland is functioning as an excellent way to avoid fiery corporate justice.

For Econ/Card Draw I focused on making the most of Professional Contacts. I don't know if this is 'best', but I find that it slots in well with my play style. The sure gamble and lucky find help you get out that early professional contacts with a minimal hit to your tempo. Modded is similar, in that it helps accelerate your early installs or get you a toolbox before you've really earned it. Magnum opus is your mid to late game Econ, unless you've gotten some lucky early accesses you will most likely need it sooner rather than later. Don't be afraid to search for it if you feel you are starting to stall on credits. This was something I struggled with at first, since I often held off on installing M.O. until far too late, now I just go for it as soon as whatever early burst Econ I drew is gone.

For R&D pressure I took two of both indexing and rdi, I'd actually like more of them since I often find myself digging for one or the other, but haven't yet found room for them.

The Akamatsu and The Toolbox give you a lot of memory to work with, often not necessary, but in longer games toolbox can really shine. I'm not sold on using 4 slots for this and am thinking about using cyber solutions and maybe freeing up a slot or two for extra r&d pressure or something else.

Some Nice to Haves: I would really like a nerve agent in here to give some hq pressure when I want it. Also, parasite at least one, I've hit double Tsurugi plus caprice on r&d twice now, and it sucks, you are basically locked out of that server. 8 credits just to play at that table, similarly a big remote with caprice at the bottom can be a problem. You have no choice, but to keep running it until you win the psi game, or alternatively you shift and apply a lot of pressure to r&d. Plascrete or some tag avoidance would be nice, but in my local meta it hasn't been necessary just yet.

name: PE fast advance
Workshop Kit
Tori Flatline with Scorched
description: Brain damage them with Tori and Data Mine or Cerebral Casts, then scorch them with the Cerebral or Snare tag.

name: The Red Bloc
description: A resource intensive deck, when a full suite of resources are down at the table, the corp must face a terrible decision. Wich resource will stay alive? This deck works better with AS, this is just an alternative version of it without it.

name: There is always a Plan B
description: A Fast Deck that forces the runner into error. Like the awesome The Thing That Should Not Be, this deck is fast and forces fast decisions. Mushin No Shin and Plan B are awesome in this kind of deck

name: Caissa Theory
description:
Chaos Theory and Deep Red is a great recipe for extra MU. The idea here is to get Overmind to do your work for you early and cheaply, with Knights providing the answer to fat ICE. With Deep Red out, Overmind is getting up to 8 power counters on installation. Each Overmind gets up to three installs -- one off of a Test Run, one out of hand, and one off of a Scavenge.

Draw like a maniac, get a loaded Overmind out, and try and pull off some Indexings and Legworks as fast as possible.

One big issue that this deck will have is with multiple-subroutine ICE on central servers. I'm not sure how to fix that problem aside from using Escher or redirecting my pressure to another server.

Comments and improvements appreciated!

name: Criminals Silhouette carillion v1.0
Jinteki Harmony Medtech carillion 1.0
Oracle Ken
description: Listen, it's silly, but fun.

name: DaggerBrush v4.2
description:
I like Dagger, I like Paintbrush. Let's make a deck with them!

I like all the recurring credits, so I'm adding in Cyberfeeders, using the influence that was previously used for a Corroder, which got replaced with a Battering Ram to help against peky Heimdalls. Forged Activation Orders got swapped for E3-s, also because of big, multi-subroutine ICE like Heimdall.

This is my current tournament deck, and this latest iteration seems like it might also be the most effective against the rising number of Glacier style decks in my local meta.

name: Brain Damage HB
description:
Agendas

Accelerated Beta Test mainly because it's a 3/2. Also I'm running 21 ICE so I trigger it more often than not. Sentinel Defense Program because it fits with the goal of the deck. Corporate War and Gila Hands Arcology because I feel the econ is needed.

Assets

Adonis Campaign and Eve Campaign for econ. I usually put these either in an unprotected remote or behind one ICE at most. Edge of World and Cerebral Overwriter to work towards the brain damage goal. Edge of World can masquerade as an ABT or Gila, Cerebral can masquerade as Sentinel or Corporate War with install, advance, advance. Jackson Howard because it's just good.

Upgrades

Corporate Troubleshooter for when they run with no actions left and with barely enough money to break your Heimdall or something. Paying quite a bit of credits to ensure a brain damage is usually worth it in this deck.

ICE

Basically just running every brain damage ICE. Inazuma is a good surprise for when they run at its server expecting to pay a few actions to get past your ICE.

name: Killer hand, bro (Portland Regionals, Top 8)
description:
My corp deck from Portland Regionals. 4-1 in Swiss, 1-1 in Double Elimination.

The changes from AKAnderson's "Killer Hand Bro" seem small, but I feel they're significant and made a meaningful difference in my success. I replaced the two Priority Requisitions with two Project Virtruvius and an Accelerated Beta Test, making it easier for this deck to switch gears and score out in a few turns when a flatline seems to be out of reach, generally due to a combination of strong runner economy, 2-3 plascretes, and Scorches not showing up. I had two scoring wins in addition to my three flatlines.

To make room for the additional card, I cut the singleton Subliminal Messaging. While it's not a bad card, its impact was marginal to begin with, and doubly so as a singleton. Additionally, not having to worry about missing the trigger made the deck less cognitively taxing in a tournament environment.

In the future, I would cut Gyri Labyrinth for ice that was either more taxing or damaging to the runner's board state. While a surprise with Gyri can be quite effective, and save both clicks and credits, I found that situation rarely came up, and the card often did nothing for me.

name: Don't Run Against a Tree (DRAT)
description:
Not sure what to say really. The deck attempts to not have Agendas stolen, or if they do get stolen it costs the Runner more than they wanted.

I'm not entirely sold on Cerebral Overwriter.

Psychic Field and Toshiyuki are there for the experimentations.

name: Sneaky Silhouette
Jinteki Does What They do Because They Can
Prepaid Kate - no Atman
description: This version has changed to make it even more event heavy - lots of bursty economy. The plan is to aim for early R&D lock, and use Legwork to pull agendas from HQ in the event of Jackson/Fast Track business.

name: FWIENDS. And Keyhole.
Rushy stuff
Free advancement stuff v0.2
Sneaky stuff
